message_1: Consider a graph G with 10 vertices. What is the minimum number of colors needed to color the vertices of G so that no two adjacent vertices have the same color?
message_2:
The minimum number of colors needed to color the vertices of a graph G with 10 vertices so that no two adjacent vertices have the same color depends on the structure of the graph. In the worst-case scenario, the graph is a complete graph (every vertex is connected to every other vertex). In this case, we can use the chromatic number formula for complete graphs:

Chromatic number = χ(G) = n if the graph is odd, and χ(G) = n + 1 if the graph is even.

Since our graph has 10 vertices, which is an even number, the minimum number of colors needed is:

χ(G) = 10 + 1 = 11 colors.
